headline.main: Republican Plan Would Not Help Economy, Firm Projects

docs.abstract: Senate Republicans' proposed jobs package would not reduce unemployment or spur the economy's growth in the next year or two, according to a forecasting firm that predicted that President Obama's plan would achieve both goals.
docs.snippet: Senate Republicans' proposed jobs package would not reduce unemployment or spur the economy's growth in the next year or two, according to a forecasting firm that predicted that President Obama's plan would achieve both goals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans' proposed jobs package would not reduce unemployment or spur the economy's growth in the next year or two, according to a leading economic forecasting firm that has predicted that President Obama's plan would achieve both goals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Narrowing Losses, Groupon Seeks $16 to $18 a Share in I.P.O.  |  Groupon reported nearly breaking even in its third quarter, an important milestone as it prepares the final leg of its long journey toward an initial public offering.

headline.main: Week 7 Matchups: When the Middling Face the Mediocre
headline.print_headline: Looking for Exciting Matchups? Take the Day Off

docs.abstract: The best and most interesting teams have byes this weekend, but the games go on.
docs.snippet: The best and most interesting teams have byes this weekend, but the games go on.

docs.lead_paragraph: Colts (0-6) at Saints (4-2)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Saints by 14.The famous quote by the former N.F.L. commissioner Bert Bell - "On any given Sunday, any team in the N.F.L. can beat any other" - has been a source of reassurance for both fans and television programmers for decades. The league's carefully maintained competitive balance almost guarantees that every week will feature several compelling games between high-quality, evenly matched opponents. Almost.Bell would never imagine a week like this, in which the best (the Patriots) and most fascinating (the Eagles, the 49ers) teams have byes, while the top contenders face pushovers and the mediocre slug it out with the middling. Matchups that looked good when the schedule was announced now merit double-digit point spreads. Case in point: the Colts vs. the Saints, a rematch of Super Bowl XLIV that promised to be a seesaw offensive battle, is now little more than a three-hour wake for Indianapolis and a chance to watch Sean Payton coach New Orleans from the booth instead of the sideline.Granted, Curtis Painter, like a frozen burrito under a filling station heat lamp, is slowly warming to the Colts' starting quarterback job. His completion percentage has gone up every week, and the Colts offense no longer looks like an intramural team playing in a downpour. Also, Drew Brees offered hope that Payton might find a way to stand on, or slightly above, the field on the surgically repaired leg he broke in last week's game. "I'm envisioning some kind of hovercraft on the sideline," Brees said. Levitating coaches: another thing that Bert Bell could never imagine. Pick: Saints.

docs.lead_paragraph: Citing rising costs, Wal-Mart is substantially rolling back coverage for part-time workers and significantly raising premiums for many full-time staff.

headline.main: Wal-Mart Cuts Some Health Care Benefits
headline.print_headline: Wal-Mart Cuts Some Health Care Benefits

docs.abstract: Wal-Mart will make substantial cuts to health care coverage for part-time workers and raise premiums for many full-time staff, citing rising costs; employees working less than 24 hours per week will have no coverage; move is seen as end to period in which company attempted to mollify critics of its benefits program.
docs.snippet: Citing rising costs, Wal-Mart is substantially rolling back coverage for part-time workers and significantly raising premiums for many full-time staff.

keywords.value: Organization United for Respect at Walmart
keywords.name: organizations

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and REED ABELSON

docs.lead_paragraph: A proposed alliance between Continuum Health Partners and NYU Langone Medical Center reflects a wider trend toward bigger medical organizations.

headline.seo: N.Y.C. Hospital Groups, Continuum and NYU, May Ally
headline.main: Two Major Hospital Groups in City Explore a Partnership
headline.print_headline: Two Major Hospital Groups In City Explore a Partnership

docs.abstract: Continuum Health Partners and NYU Langone Medical Center, two of New York City's major hospital organizations, are exploring a partnership that would give them a large share of the city's patients and make them a formidable rival for other city hospitals in tough economic times.
docs.snippet: A proposed alliance between Continuum Health Partners and NYU Langone Medical Center reflects a wider trend toward bigger medical organizations.

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Many Americans will continue to see the Amish as a backward cult, but many more will persist in mythologizing them, seeing in them what they need to see.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans approved an egregious measure last week that would shrink access to abortion to the point of endangering women’s lives.
docs.abstract: Editorial abhors egregious House measure that would allow hospitals to refuse to perform an abortion on religious or moral grounds even if woman's life is at stake; says, while measure has little chance of becoming law, bill is another warning that supporters of women's reproductive rights need to push back a lot harder.
docs.snippet: House Republicans approved an egregious measure last week that would shrink access to abortion to the point of endangering women’s lives.
